content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and certainty, I would choose the option that offers me a consistent return over the long term, which is the B option in this case, earning 12$ per round. While R has the potential for higher returns in some rounds (45$), it also carries the risk of no return (0$) if my anonymous partner chooses B. Over 75 rounds, the consistent earnings from choosing B would likely outweigh the occasional larger payout from choosing R. However, this is a game-theoretical analysis and behavior in real life may differ due to factors such as human psychology and potential adaptations by the anonymous player over time. I am choosing B, but it's important to remember that human decision-making can be complex and unpredictable. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both me (choosing B) and my opponent (also choosing B) received a payoff of 12$ in the first round. Given that we both chose B, I will stick to my strategy and choose B again for the next round. {B}
